abstract: After two men won their appeal to have their convictions overturned in a case referred to as the Enron of Kansas, The New York Times takes a look at the latest in a recent series of setbacks for the government in white-collar cases. In September 2005, David C. Wittig, a former star investment banker, and his lieutenant, Douglas T. Lake, were convicted of looting the company they ran, Westar Energy of Topeka, the largest electric utility in Kansas. Mr. Wittig was sentenced to 18 years in prison, and Mr. Lake, 15 years. But last Friday, a federal appeals court overturned the convictions of the two men on all 40 counts – most of which cannot be retried.
lead_paragraph: After two men won their appeal to have their convictions overturned in a case referred to as the Enron of Kansas, The New York Times takes a look at the latest in a recent series of setbacks for the government in white-collar cases. In September 2005, David C. Wittig, a former star investment banker, and his lieutenant, Douglas T. Lake, were convicted of looting the company they ran, Westar Energy of Topeka, the largest electric utility in Kansas. Mr. Wittig was sentenced to 18 years in prison, and Mr. Lake, 15 years. But last Friday, a federal appeals court overturned the convictions of the two men on all 40 counts – most of which cannot be retried.

headline.main: A Setback for Prosecutors in the ‘Enron of Kansas’ Case
